channel.title: YouTube: .FLV Video
channel.description:
Okay, So i was wondering how websites like http://keepvid.com works. Where is the .flv video stored in you tube? Before you fast reply being a smart arse and say look at the page source on you tube. I have and the only thing I can find the flash vars and such as "video_id" and "title". Whe I go to the URL that the variables point me to I just get the actual flash object.
There might just be something i'm missing but it got me wondering and it sort of annoys me now.
Any reply appreciated as long as you don't flame =)

item.title: YouTube: .FLV Video
item.dc:creator: @Buzzy Buzzy
item.description:
@Buzzy wrote:

SETO:

youtube vids get stored in u r temp file (if using IE , If firefox duno sry)

lmfao, so your telling me every youtube vid is in your temp files atm? no. theyre stored in the server. i don’t know exactly where, but they probably sort them by user. like:

http://www.youtube.com/[b]user[/b]/vid.flv

except a lot more complex than in two paths. also, i know you don’t want to dl them, but if your doing this so you can stream them from a flash applet, try dl-ing them, and then uploading them to another site, that way you have the path because I doubt your going to find youtubes vid source path. sorry if this doesnt help at all, and your welcome if it did.

Read full topic

item.title: YouTube: .FLV Video

@Martin wrote:

Wow, that would make you the second person to realise that…? how many times are people going to tell me how to use someone elses code to do it and not how it works. =O

item.title: YouTube: .FLV Video
item.dc:creator: @teh_spede Teh Spede
item.description:
@teh_spede wrote:

[quote=“Project 69, post:8, topic:106893”]Or you can do this if you are using FireFox:

  1. Download Greasemonkey (Google it).

  2. Install this script.

  3. Go to Youtube and download the videos as you are watching them by clicking a link that says “Download this Video” right under the video player itself.

  4. Save as a file with a .flv extension.

  5. Open in VLC media player or some other media player that supports .flvs[/quote]

He doesnt want to know how to download the videos! He wants to know how they store them!

Read full topic

item.title: YouTube: .FLV Video
item.dc:creator: @Project_69 Project 69
item.description:
@Project_69 wrote:

Or you can do this if you are using FireFox:

  1. Download Greasemonkey (Google it).

  2. Install this script.

  3. Go to Youtube and download the videos as you are watching them by clicking a link that says “Download this Video” right under the video player itself.

  4. Save as a file with a .flv extension.

  5. Open in VLC media player or some other media player that supports .flvs

Read full topic

item.title: YouTube: .FLV Video
item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

OR you could do this:
http://www.mediapirate.org/grabit.php?url=

And after the url= put the url without anyspaces e.g:
http://www.mediapirate.org/grabit.php?url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PhMeDIwVYAY

Read full topic

item.title: YouTube: .FLV Video
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

I don’t know specifically where the videos are stored. But they are accessed through a utility called “get_video” and follows the form of:

http://youtube.com/get_video?video_id=[Video ID]&t=[Whatever t stands for]

You can get these two values from the source when you load a video on youtube’s website…its located in the writeMoviePlayer JS function, if you need a reference.

Read full topic
